intro: Chlora lanceolata var. serotina, commonly known as the late-flowering chlora, is a perennial herbaceous plant native to certain regions of North America. It belongs to the Apiaceae family, characterized by its aromatic foliage and umbellate flowers. The plant typically grows in moist, shaded environments such as woodlands and stream banks. Its leaves are lance-shaped and have a distinct, peppery aroma when crushed. The flowers bloom later in the season, usually in late summer or early autumn, contributing to its common name.
